title: Add Claude plugins API to tabz MCP server
description:
## Overview

Expose the existing TabzChrome plugins API via MCP tools, allowing Claude to discover and manage available plugins/skills.

## Existing REST API Endpoints

Already implemented in TabzChrome:
- `GET /api/plugins` - List all installed plugins with components
- `GET /api/plugins/skills` - Get skills with trigger phrases
- `GET /api/plugins/health` - Check for outdated versions
- `POST /api/plugins/toggle` - Enable/disable plugins
- `POST /api/plugins/update` - Update a plugin

## Proposed MCP Tools

### tabz_list_plugins
List installed plugins:
```typescript
tabz_list_plugins({
  marketplace?: "my-plugins",  // Optional: filter by marketplace
  enabled?: true               // Optional: filter by enabled status
})
```

### tabz_list_skills
List available skills with descriptions:
```typescript
tabz_list_skills({
  plugin?: "conductor",        // Optional: filter by plugin name
  search?: "browser"           // Optional: search descriptions
})
```

Returns skill ID, name, description, trigger phrases.

### tabz_get_skill
Get full details of a skill:
```typescript
tabz_get_skill({
  skillId: "/conductor:brainstorm"
})
```

Returns skill content/SKILL.md for context.

### tabz_plugins_health
Check plugin health:
```typescript
tabz_plugins_health()
```

Returns outdated plugins, cache size, issues.

### tabz_toggle_plugin
Enable/disable a plugin:
```typescript
tabz_toggle_plugin({
  pluginId: "conductor@my-plugins",
  enabled: false
})
```

## Use Cases

**Conductor finding relevant skills for a task:**
```python
skills = mcp__tabz__tabz_list_skills(search="code review")
# Returns skills matching "code review" in description
```

**Worker discovering what's available:**
```python
mcp__tabz__tabz_list_skills(plugin="conductor")
# Returns all conductor skills
```

**Checking if plugins need updates:**
```python
mcp__tabz__tabz_plugins_health()
# Returns any outdated plugins
```

## Implementation

Location: `tabz-mcp-server/src/tools/plugins.ts` (new file)

Simply wraps the existing REST API endpoints.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `tabz_list_plugins` - list plugins with optional filters
- [ ] `tabz_list_skills` - list skills with search
- [ ] `tabz_get_skill` - get skill details
- [ ] `tabz_plugins_health` - check health
- [ ] `tabz_toggle_plugin` - enable/disable
- [ ] Tools documented in MCP_TOOLS.md
notes:
## Retro
- Straightforward implementation wrapping existing REST API
- Used existing tool patterns from other tools (tabs.ts, downloads.ts, etc.)
- Added 5 new MCP tools: tabz_list_plugins, tabz_list_skills, tabz_get_skill, tabz_plugins_health, tabz_toggle_plugin
- Tools registered in new 'plugins' tool group (enabled by default)
- MCP_TOOLS.md updated with documentation and trigger phrases
- Tool count increased from 71 to 76

title: Watcher: reuse low-context workers for follow-up tasks
description:
When a worker completes a task with low context usage (<50%), don't kill them. Instead:

1. Detect completion + check context % from tmuxplexer/state
2. If context < 50%, check `bd ready` for related unblocked issues
3. Send next task to same worker via tmux send-keys
4. Only kill when context >= 50% or no related tasks available

## Benefits
- Workers already have skills/plugins loaded
- CLAUDE.md and codebase understanding preserved
- Faster task completion (no cold start)
- More efficient token usage

## Related task detection
Could match by:
- Same component/area (inferred from file paths)
- Same type (feature, bug, task)
- Explicit `related_to` field in beads
- Priority order if no better match

## Implementation
Update watcher.md pipeline:
```
WORKER_DONE + context < 50%:
  → Check bd ready for related tasks
  → If found: send new task prompt
  → If none: proceed to cleanup

WORKER_DONE + context >= 50%:
  → Proceed to cleanup (worker is tired)
```

## Files
- plugins/conductor/agents/watcher.md
- plugins/conductor/commands/bd-swarm.md (document behavior)
close_reason: Worker reuse implemented in watcher.md

2. No record of which Claude sessions worked on which issues

```markdown
## Conductor
Session: ctt-amber-claude-b3b8f451
Notify on completion: tmux send-keys -t <session> ...
```

**3. On completion, update notes:**
```bash
bd update $ISSUE_ID --notes "$(bd show $ISSUE_ID --json | jq -r .notes)\ncompleted_at: $(date -Iseconds)\ncommit: $SHA"
```

**Benefits:**
- Reliable worker→conductor notification (session in prompt, not env)
- Full audit trail: which session worked on what, when
- Can review Claude transcripts later to improve prompts
- Debug failed/stuck workers by checking their session history

title: Add profile-based spawning to /api/agents endpoint
description:
## Problem

Currently `/api/agents` requires full config:
```json
{"terminalType": "claude", "name": "worker", "command": "claude --agent codex-reviewer", "workingDir": "..."}
```

But profiles already define all this - command, theme, fonts, etc. Spawning by profile would be cleaner:
```json
{"profileId": "codex-reviewer", "workingDir": ".worktrees/bd-abc"}
```

## Proposed Change

Add optional `profileId` to spawn schema:
1. If `profileId` provided, fetch profile from Chrome storage via existing `/api/browser/profiles` 
2. Merge profile settings with any overrides (workingDir, env, etc.)
3. Spawn using merged config

## Security Note

This doesn't change the security model - custom commands can already be passed. The auth token is the security gate.

## Use Case

Conductor spawning checkpoint profiles:
```bash
curl -X POST http://localhost:8129/api/agents \
  -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" \
  -d '{"profileId": "codex-reviewer", "workingDir": ".worktrees/bd-abc"}'
```

## Files to Modify

- `backend/routes/api.js` - Add profileId to schema, lookup logic
- `backend/modules/unified-spawn.js` - Handle profile resolution

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Can spawn terminal by profileId
- [ ] Profile settings (command, theme, etc.) are applied
- [ ] Can override workingDir, env, name
- [ ] Returns same response format as current spawn
notes:
## Retro

- Used makeBrowserRequest from browser.js (had to export it)
- The profile fetch works via WebSocket to Chrome extension
- Terminal type inference from command handles common AI tools (claude, gemini, codex, opencode, docker ai)
- Defaults to 'bash' for profiles without recognized AI commands

title: Create spawn-worker.sh for direct spawning without haiku subagent
description:
## Problem
Currently spawning workers goes through a haiku subagent which adds latency and round-trips. The conductor has to delegate to Task(prompt='/spawner:spawn ISSUE') which then loads the skill, figures out the steps, etc.

## Solution
Create a pure bash script spawn-worker.sh that the conductor can call directly:

```bash
./spawn-worker.sh ISSUE-ID [--no-deps] [--quiet]
```

## Script should:
1. Pre-flight: Check TabzChrome health, verify issue is ready
2. Create worktree: git worktree add .worktrees/ISSUE -b feature/ISSUE
3. Spawn terminal via TabzChrome API (dont wait for deps)
4. Background deps init: Run init-worktree.sh in background (parallel with Claude 8s boot)
5. Wait for Claude boot (8s)
6. Send pep-talk prompt via safe-send-keys.sh
7. Update beads: bd update ISSUE --status in_progress
8. Output JSON: {id, terminal_id, worktree_path, branch}

## Key insight
Deps install can happen AFTER spawn since Claude takes 8s to boot anyway. This overlaps the 30-60s init time with boot time.

## Files
- plugins/spawner/scripts/spawn-worker.sh (new)
- plugins/conductor/commands/auto.md (update to call script directly)

title: Build skills-marketplace MCP for autonomous skill discovery and installation
description:
Create a skill discovery system for Conductor workflows.

## Problem
- Conductor spawns workers for parallel tasks but skill selection is manual
- 28k+ skills on skillsmp.com with no programmatic access
- Workers need tailored expertise for their task

## Solution Options to Explore

### Option 1: MCP-powered marketplace
- Supabase database with full-text search
- MCP tools: search_skills, get_skill, install_skill
- Downloads .md files to worktree/.claude/prompts/

### Option 2: GitHub repository with @ references
- Skills stored as .md files in repo (e.g., github.com/yourname/claude-skills)
- Conductor uses @ file references in opening prompt
- Example: `@github.com/yourname/claude-skills/react-forms-expert.md`
- Zero infrastructure needed - Claude's native @ system handles it
- Works with remote URLs or local file paths

### Option 3: Hybrid approach
- Public skills in GitHub repo (@ reference)
- Private/custom skills in Supabase (MCP)
- Best of both worlds

## Key Insight: Skills as Opening Prompts
Skills don't need complex plugin system - just .md files that end with:
"Do not respond to this message. The user will begin the conversation below."

No activation issues, no manifest.json, no loading logic - just prepend markdown to conversation.

## Decision Needed
Which approach balances:
- Simplicity (GitHub @ refs win)
- Searchability (Supabase/MCP wins)
- Infrastructure (GitHub wins - zero setup)
- Discoverability (needs UI either way)
design:
## MCP Tools

1. **search_skills(query, tags?, category?, limit?)** - Full-text search
2. **get_skill(skill_id)** - Fetch full skill content + metadata
3. **install_skill(skill_id, target_dir, plugin_name?)** - Write to worktree .claude/plugins/
4. **batch_install(skill_ids[], target_dir)** - Install multiple skills
5. **recommend_skills(task_description, max_results?)** - AI-powered recommendations

## Supabase Schema
```sql
create table skills (
  id text primary key,
  plugin_name text not null,
  skill_name text not null,
  full_name text generated,
  description text,
  content text,
  tags text[],
  category text,
  author text,
  downloads integer default 0,
  dependencies jsonb,
  search_vector tsvector  -- Full-text search
);
```

## Conductor Workflow
```bash
Issue: "Fix React form validation"
→ search_skills("react forms validation typescript")
→ Results: [ui-styling, frontend-development, shadcn-ui]
→ Setup worktree: git worktree add ../TabzChrome-abc
→ batch_install(["ui-styling", "frontend-development"], "../TabzChrome-abc")
→ Spawn worker with skills pre-installed
```

title: Subagent skills: frontmatter loads full skill content instead of progressive disclosure
description:
When spawning subagents with `skills:` frontmatter, the full content of every listed skill is loaded into context immediately. This causes agents to start with 30-40k tokens used before doing any work.

Expected behavior per CLAUDE.md:
- Skills load as ~200 tokens until invoked
- Full content loads only when skill is actually used

Current behavior:
- All skills in frontmatter are fully expanded into context at spawn time
- This defeats the purpose of progressive disclosure
design:
## Root Cause

This is a **Claude Code platform-level issue**, not fixable in plugin code.

The `skills:` YAML frontmatter in agents is parsed by Claude Code when spawning agents. The platform loads **full skill content** instead of ~200 token stubs.

## Affected Conductor Agents

| Agent | Skills | Expected Tokens | Actual Tokens |
|-------|--------|-----------------|---------------|
| prompt-drafter | sequential-thinking | ~200 | ~5000+ |
| tabz-artist | canvas-design, mermaidjs-v11 | ~400 | ~15000+ |
| prompt-engineer | sequential-thinking | ~200 | ~5000+ |

## Code Path (Claude Code internals)

```
when spawning agent:
  read agent.md file
  parse YAML frontmatter
  get skills: [skill-name]
  
  for each skill:
    lookup skill file
    // BUG: Should load stub (~200 tokens)
    // ACTUAL: Loads full SKILL.md content
    include_in_context(full_skill_content)  // WRONG
```

## Plugin-Level Workaround

Since we cannot fix Claude Code internals:
1. Remove `skills:` frontmatter from affected agents
2. Document in agent system prompt which skills to invoke
3. Agents call skills via `Task(skill: "name")` when needed

This sacrifices the declarative `skills:` pattern but achieves the same token savings.
acceptance_criteria:
- Subagents with skills: frontmatter start with <5k tokens from skills
- Full skill content only loads when skill is invoked
- No regression in skill functionality when invoked
notes:
## Resolution (2026-01-08)

**Resolved by architectural change** - removed the subagent pattern entirely instead of fixing the `skills:` frontmatter loading bug.

### Changes Made

1. **Disabled subagents plugin** - Set `subagents@my-plugins: false` in settings.json
2. **Removed duplicate skills/** - Deleted 55MB / 590 files from my-plugins
3. **Reverted conductor to skill-aware prompts** - Workers invoke skills directly (e.g., `/xterm-js`) instead of through subagents
4. **Updated conductor docs** - bd-swarm.md, bd-swarm-auto, worker-architecture.md now use skill hints pattern

### Commits

- `my-plugins@4451fff` - refactor: remove duplicate skills/ directory
- `TabzChrome@4fac77a` - refactor(conductor): revert to skill-aware prompts, remove subagent worker pattern

### Token Results

| Metric | Before | After |
|--------|--------|-------|
| Custom agents | 1.4k tokens | 660 tokens |
| Total context | 35k tokens | 27k tokens |

### Why This Approach

The subagent pattern (frontend-builder, backend-builder, etc.) created a 3-layer context explosion:
1. Worker loads
2. Worker invokes subagent
3. Subagent invokes skills

By having workers invoke skills directly, we eliminate the middle layer and avoid the `skills:` frontmatter bug entirely.
close_reason: Resolved by removing subagent pattern entirely. Workers now invoke skills directly, eliminating the 3-layer context explosion and avoiding the skills: frontmatter bug.

title: Gate-driven conductor loop
description:
## Overview

Simple conductor that reads gates from beads issues and spawns checkpoint profiles to resolve them.

## Flow

```
1. Poll for issues with pending gates
2. For each issue:
   a. Get next pending gate
   b. Spawn checkpoint profile (by profileId)
   c. Wait for terminal to exit
   d. Read result file
   e. bd gate resolve <gate-id> or reopen issue
3. All gates passed? Merge to main
4. Repeat
```

## Implementation

Could be:
- Bash script (simplest, most reliable)
- Update to existing `/conductor:auto` command
- New `/conductor:gate-runner` command

## Key Functions

```bash
# Get issues with pending gates
bd list --json | jq '.[] | select(.gates.pending | length > 0)'

# Spawn checkpoint by profile
curl -X POST http://localhost:8129/api/agents \
  -d '{"profileId": "codex-reviewer", "workingDir": ".worktrees/$ISSUE"}'

# Resolve gate
bd gate resolve $GATE_ID --result '{"passed": true}'

# Or reopen on failure
bd reopen $ISSUE --reason "Gate failed: $RESULT"
```

## Depends On

- TabzChrome-1sc (profile spawning)
- TabzChrome-jm0 (checkpoint profiles exist)
- TabzChrome-qg9 (checkpoint skills exist)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Conductor detects issues with pending gates
- [ ] Spawns correct profile for each gate type
- [ ] Reads checkpoint result
- [ ] Resolves gates or reopens issues
- [ ] Merges when all gates pass

6. Monitor for completion notifications
7. Merge completed branches
8. Run unified code review (spawn reviewer terminal)
9. Run visual QA (spawn tabz-manager terminal)
10. Cleanup worktrees
11. Loop for next wave or complete

title: Conductor: poll tmuxplexer pane instead of watcher subagent
description:
## Current Problem
The watcher is a separate subagent that:
- Burns context on monitoring
- Detected stuck workers but didn't nudge properly
- Would incorrectly nudge workers waiting on AskUserQuestion

## Simpler Approach
Remove watcher subagent. Conductor monitors via background window in its own session.

### 1. Spawn tmuxplexer in background window
```bash
# TabzChrome windows start at 1
# Window 1: conductor/claude (main)
# Window 2: tmuxplexer --watcher (background monitor)

# Check if monitor window exists, create if not
if ! tmux list-windows -F '#{window_name}' | grep -q "^monitor$"; then
  tmux new-window -d -n "monitor" "tmuxplexer --watcher"
fi
```

User can click status bar to switch to monitor window if they want to see it.

### 2. Periodic pane capture (every ~2 min)
```bash
tmux capture-pane -t ":monitor" -p
```

Output shows per-worker: session name, status, context %, current tool

### 3. Decision logic
Parse tmuxplexer output:
- `awaiting_input` → User question pending, don't nudge
- `processing` / `tool_use` → Working, leave alone  
- `idle` + issue still open → Check worker pane for details
- Issue closed → Worker done, can cleanup

### 4. Drill down only when needed
```bash
# Only if worker looks stuck, capture their actual pane
tmux capture-pane -t <worker-session> -p -S -50
```

## Benefits
- No separate watcher subagent
- Background window in conductor's session (not cluttering user's view)
- User can switch to monitor window via status bar if curious
- Single pane capture = all worker statuses
- Conductor retains full context for decisions

title: Fix /conductor:auto tmux send-keys timing
description:
## Problem

The auto.md skill has inline tmux send-keys that can fail for long prompts:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t "$SESSION" -l "$PROMPT"
sleep 1
tmux send-keys -t "$SESSION" Enter
```

## Solution

Use the existing `scripts/safe-send-keys.sh` which already handles:
- Session validation
- Literal text mode (`-l`)
- Delay before Enter
- Proper `C-m` for Enter

However, the current 0.3s delay in safe-send-keys.sh may not be enough for long prompts that wrap in Claude Code's terminal.

## Changes Needed

1. **Update safe-send-keys.sh** - Increase default delay or make it configurable:
```bash
# Option A: Increase default delay
sleep 1  # instead of 0.3

# Option B: Make delay configurable
DELAY=${SEND_KEYS_DELAY:-1}
sleep $DELAY

# Option C: Add --delay flag
safe-send-keys.sh SESSION "text" --delay 1.5
```

2. **Update /conductor:auto** to use the script:
```bash
# Instead of inline tmux commands:
./scripts/safe-send-keys.sh "$SESSION" "$PROMPT"

# Or with custom delay for long prompts:
SEND_KEYS_DELAY=1.5 ./scripts/safe-send-keys.sh "$SESSION" "$PROMPT"
```

3. **Update conductor plugin** to reference TabzChrome's safe-send-keys.sh or copy the pattern

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] safe-send-keys.sh delay is sufficient for long prompts (1s+ recommended)
- [ ] /conductor:auto uses safe-send-keys.sh instead of inline tmux
- [ ] Conductor plugin documentation references safe-send-keys.sh pattern

title: Refactor conductor workflows into composable atomic commands
description:
## IMPORTANT: Create Backup First

Before refactoring, create a backup of the current conductor plugin state:
```bash
cp -r plugins/conductor plugins/conductor-backup-20260106
```

This ensures we can recover if the refactor breaks existing workflows.
design:
## Problem

Current `worker-done` skill is monolithic - all steps run together, hard to customize or swap implementations.

## Solution: Composable Commands

Each pipeline step becomes an atomic command in `plugins/conductor/commands/`:

### Proposed Atomic Commands

| Command | Purpose | Notes |
|---------|---------|-------|
| `/verify-build` | Run build, report errors | |
| `/run-tests` | Run tests if available | |
| `/code-review` | Opus review with auto-fix | Spawns conductor:code-reviewer agent |
| `/codex-review` | Codex review (read-only) | Runs `codex review --uncommitted`, cheaper |
| `/commit-changes` | Stage + commit with conventional format | |
| `/create-followups` | Analyze for follow-up issues | Important for research tasks |
| `/update-docs` | Check/update documentation | |
| `/close-issue` | Close beads issue | |

### Orchestrator Commands

`/worker-done` becomes an orchestrator that calls atomic commands:

```
/verify-build && /run-tests && /code-review && /commit-changes && /close-issue
```

### Example Compositions

```bash
# Standard completion
/verify-build && /run-tests && /code-review && /commit-changes && /close-issue

# Quick completion (skip review)
/verify-build && /commit-changes && /close-issue

# Codex review instead of Opus (cheaper, read-only)
/verify-build && /run-tests && /codex-review && /commit-changes && /close-issue

# Research task (needs followups)
/verify-build && /code-review && /commit-changes && /create-followups && /close-issue
```

## Codex Review Details

Codex CLI v0.77.0 has purpose-built `codex review` command:

```bash
codex review --uncommitted -C $WORKTREE
codex review --base main -C $WORKTREE
```

- Inherently read-only (no --sandbox needed)
- Cheaper than Opus (~$0.02 vs ~$0.15 per review)
- Has access to Tabz MCP and Beads MCP
- Output is natural language (needs parsing to JSON for conductor)

### Trade-offs: Opus vs Codex Review

| Aspect | Opus code-reviewer | Codex codex-review |
|--------|-------------------|--------------------|
| Auto-fix | Yes (Edit tools) | No (read-only) |
| Cost | Higher | Lower |
| Speed | Slower | Faster |
| MCP access | Via Claude | Native |
| Output | Structured JSON | Parse NL to JSON |

## File Structure After Refactor

```
plugins/conductor/
├── commands/
│   ├── verify-build.md      # NEW atomic
│   ├── run-tests.md         # NEW atomic
│   ├── code-review.md       # NEW atomic (wraps agent)
│   ├── codex-review.md      # NEW atomic (runs codex CLI)
│   ├── commit-changes.md    # NEW atomic
│   ├── create-followups.md  # NEW atomic
│   ├── update-docs.md       # NEW atomic
│   ├── close-issue.md       # NEW atomic
│   ├── worker-done.md       # NEW orchestrator
│   ├── bd-swarm.md          # existing
│   └── ...
├── skills/
│   └── worker-done/         # can remove after migration
└── agents/
    └── code-reviewer.md     # keep for /code-review to spawn
```

## Benefits

- **Customization**: Mix & match commands for different workflows
- **Testing**: Test single steps in isolation
- **Swap implementations**: Use `/codex-review` instead of `/code-review`
- **Recovery**: Resume from failed step instead of re-running everything
- **New workflows**: Compose existing commands instead of writing new skills

1. Each atomic command works standalone
2. `/worker-done` orchestrator calls atomic commands in sequence
3. `/codex-review` runs Codex CLI and parses output to JSON
4. Commands can be composed in different orders
5. Existing bd-swarm workflow still functions

title: Replace tmux send-keys worker notifications with API-based system
description:
## Problem
Workers notify the conductor of completion via tmux send-keys, which can corrupt the conductor's Claude session if it's mid-output or mid-prompt.

Current pattern (risky):
```bash
tmux send-keys -t CONDUCTOR -l "WORKER COMPLETE: ..."
sleep 0.3
tmux send-keys -t CONDUCTOR C-m
```

## Solution
Use TabzChrome's existing WebSocket broadcast infrastructure for worker-to-conductor notifications.

### 1. Add /api/notify endpoint
```javascript
// POST /api/notify
app.post('/api/notify', (req, res) => {
  const { type, issueId, summary, session } = req.body;
  broadcast({ type: 'worker-notification', data: { type, issueId, summary, session } });
  res.json({ success: true });
});
```

### 2. Worker notifies via API
```bash
curl -X POST http://localhost:8129/api/notify \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" \
  -d '{"type": "worker-complete", "issueId": "TabzChrome-abc", "summary": "Fixed bug", "session": "ctt-worker-xxx"}'
```

### 3. Conductor receives via WebSocket (or polls /api/notifications)

## Benefits
- No tmux keystrokes to active Claude session
- Async - conductor processes when ready
- No risk of corrupting input
- Fire-and-forget from worker perspective

title: Purpose-built agents with curated skills + skillsmp for agent creation
description:
Create purpose-built subagents for each workflow step, using skillsmp to curate the best skills during agent creation.

## Architecture

```
Workflow Step → Slash Command → Agent (curated skills in frontmatter)
```

Skills are baked into agents at creation time, not discovered at runtime.

## Agent Creation Workflow

When creating a new agent:
1. Identify what the agent needs to do
2. Search skillsmp for relevant skills
3. **Filter by stars** (default: >10 stars for quality)
4. **Niche exception**: For uncommon tech stacks, relax filter to include lower-starred skills
5. Preview top candidates, select best fits
6. Bake selected skills into agent frontmatter

```bash
# Default: popular skills only
curl "https://skillsmp.com/api/v1/skills/ai-search?q=terminal+rendering" | jq '.data.data[] | select(.skill.stars > 10)'

# Niche tech: include all
curl "https://skillsmp.com/api/v1/skills/ai-search?q=bubbletea+TUI" | jq '.data.data[:5]'
```

## Purpose-Built Agents

| Agent | Skills | Purpose |
|-------|--------|--------|
| `prompt-drafter` | pmux, code-review | Draft pmux-style prompts per issue |
| `worker-frontend` | ui-styling, web-frameworks, frontend-development | Frontend tasks |
| `worker-terminal` | xterm-js | Terminal/PTY tasks |
| `worker-backend` | backend-development, databases | API/server tasks |
| `worker-devops` | devops, docker-mcp | Infrastructure tasks |

## Slash Commands Per Step

| Command | Agent | Purpose |
|---------|-------|--------|
| `/plan-backlog` | plan-backlog | Analyze issues into waves |
| `/draft-prompts` | prompt-drafter | Generate pmux-style prompts |
| `/spawn-wave` | initializer | Setup worktrees, spawn workers |
| `/monitor-wave` | (script) | Poll worker status |
| `/complete-wave` | completion-pipeline | Merge, cleanup |

User runs each step to verify, or chains them.

## Skill Quality Filter

```
Default filter:     stars > 10 (quality guarantee)
Niche tech filter:  stars > 0  (include emerging skills)
Manual override:    user picks specific skill regardless of stars
```

## Benefits

1. **Verifiable** - User can run each slash command to see exactly what happens
2. **Curated quality** - Skills vetted via stars + manual review
3. **No runtime overhead** - Skills baked in, not discovered
4. **Composable** - Chain commands or run individually

title: Create prompt-writer plugin
description:
Create a focused plugin that crafts worker prompts from backlog issues.

## Components
- commands/write.md - /prompt-writer:write <issue-id>
- agents/writer.md - Haiku agent that does the work
- skills/prompt-craft/ - Best practices, natural triggers, skill discovery

## Behavior
1. Read issue from backlog status
2. Search relevant skills via tabz_list_skills MCP
3. Quick file exploration (3-5 key files)
4. Craft prompt with:
   - Role definition ("You are a...")
   - Natural skill triggers ("Use the X skill to...")
   - Subagent hints ("Use subagents in parallel to...")
   - Key files to start with
5. Store as prepared.prompt in issue notes
6. Move issue: backlog → ready

## Model
Haiku - this is a focused, fast task

## Key Prompt Engineering Principles (from Claude 4 best practices)

Reference: https://platform.claude.com/docs/en/build-with-claude/prompt-engineering/claude-4-best-practices

### Be Explicit
Claude 4.x follows instructions precisely. "Suggest changes" means suggest, not implement.
- Less effective: "Can you suggest improvements?"
- More effective: "Change this function to improve performance."

### Add Context/Motivation
Explain WHY, not just WHAT. Claude generalizes from explanations.
- Less effective: "NEVER use ellipses"
- More effective: "Never use ellipses since the TTS engine won't know how to pronounce them."

### Natural Skill Triggers
Don't use aggressive language that causes overtriggering:
- Avoid: "CRITICAL: You MUST use this tool when..."
- Use: "Use this tool when..."

### Subagent Orchestration
Claude 4.5 naturally delegates to subagents when beneficial. Prompt with:
"Use subagents in parallel to explore the codebase first."

### Parallel Tool Calls
Encourage parallel execution for independent operations:
"If you intend to call multiple tools with no dependencies, make all independent calls in parallel."

### Avoid Overengineering Prompts
Workers should receive focused prompts that:
- Tell Claude what to DO (positive framing)
- Explain the goal and context
- Reference existing patterns in the codebase
- Avoid excessive ALL CAPS or MUST/NEVER language

## References
- https://platform.claude.com/docs/en/build-with-claude/prompt-engineering/claude-4-best-practices
- TabzBeads worker-prompt-guidelines.md
- TabzBeads match-skills.sh patterns

title: Audit plugins for Opus 4.5 best practices per Anthropic guidance
description:
Analyze and update all conductor/plugin agent prompts based on Anthropic's official Opus 4.5 migration guide.

## Source
https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/tree/main/plugins/claude-opus-4-5-migration

## Opus 4.5 Behavioral Differences to Address

### 1. Tool Overtriggering
Opus 4.5 is more responsive to system prompts. Aggressive language may cause overtriggering.

**Find and soften:**
- `CRITICAL:` → remove or soften
- `You MUST...` → `You should...`
- `ALWAYS do X` → `Do X`
- `NEVER skip...` → `Don't skip...`
- `REQUIRED` → remove or soften

### 2. Over-Engineering Prevention
Opus 4.5 tends to create extra files, add unnecessary abstractions.

**Add to relevant agents:**
```
- Avoid over-engineering. Only make changes that are directly requested or clearly necessary.
- Don't add features, refactor code, or make "improvements" beyond what was asked.
- Don't create helpers, utilities, or abstractions for one-time operations.
```

### 3. Code Exploration
Opus 4.5 can propose solutions without reading files.

**Add to relevant agents:**
```
ALWAYS read and understand relevant files before proposing code edits. Do not speculate about code you have not inspected.
```

### 4. Frontend Design Quality
Default outputs may look generic.

**Add `<frontend_aesthetics>` block to UI-focused agents** with guidance on typography, color, motion, backgrounds.

When extended thinking is NOT enabled, Opus 4.5 is sensitive to "think".

title: bd-swarm --auto: fully autonomous backlog completion
description:
Add auto mode to bd-swarm that orchestrates the entire backlog to completion without user interaction.

## Concept
`/bd-swarm --auto` runs until backlog is empty:

1. **Wave N**: Spawn workers for ALL ready (unblocked) issues
   - Each worker gets a worktree
   - All run in parallel
2. **Monitor**: Watcher handles review → docs → merge → push
3. **Check**: When wave completes, `bd ready` for newly unblocked
4. **Repeat**: Spawn Wave N+1 for new ready issues
5. **Context check**: If conductor hits 75%, /wipe with handoff
6. **Exit**: When `bd ready` returns empty → 'Backlog complete\!'

## Auto Mode Differences
- **No AskUserQuestion** - autonomous decisions
- **Wave-based parallelization** - all unblocked run together
- **Self-healing** - /wipe + beads = full state recovery
- **Runs to completion** - not just one wave

## State Recovery After /wipe
Beads issues contain all state:
- Which issues are open/closed/in_progress
- Dependencies (what's blocked)
- Worktree locations (in issue comments or naming)

Handoff just needs:
```markdown
## Auto-Swarm in Progress
Wave 3 of backlog processing.
Run `/bd-swarm --auto` to continue.
```

## Decision Making (No User Questions)
| Decision | Auto Mode Choice |
|----------|------------------|
| How many workers? | All ready issues (up to 5) |
| Which skills? | Match from context |
| Review failed? | Nudge worker, wait |
| Worker stuck? | Kill after 10min, requeue issue |

## Example Run
```
$ claude '/bd-swarm --auto'

Wave 1: Spawning 3 workers (TabzChrome-abc, def, ghi)
...workers complete...
Merged, docs updated, pushed.

Wave 2: Spawning 2 workers (TabzChrome-jkl, mno) [were blocked by abc]
...workers complete...
Merged, docs updated, pushed.

Context at 78% - running /wipe...
[session clears, handoff sent]

Continuing auto-swarm...
Wave 3: Spawning 1 worker (TabzChrome-pqr)
...worker completes...

bd ready: no issues
Backlog complete\! 6 issues closed across 3 waves.
```

title: Refactor conductor to progressive disclosure plugin, remove orchestration overhead
description:
## Vision

Conductor should be a **progressive disclosure plugin** that unlocks Chrome/Tabz capabilities, not an orchestration layer that suppresses Claude's native behavior.

**Current problem:** Over-structured prompts make Claude think "I am the worker following steps" instead of naturally using subagents, parallel exploration, and divide-and-conquer strategies.

**Goal:** Force-multiply native Claude. One terminal can last an hour without context limits if subagents are used naturally.

## Architecture

```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    CLAUDE                           │
│  (natural behavior: explore, plan, parallelize)     │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
         │              │              │
         ▼              ▼              ▼
┌─────────────┐  ┌─────────────┐  ┌─────────────┐
│   BEADS     │  │  CONDUCTOR  │  │   SKILLS    │
│  (memory)   │  │  (browser   │  │  (domain    │
│  - tracking │  │   unlock)   │  │   knowledge)│
│  - history  │  │  - tabz MCP │  │  - xterm-js │
│  - deps     │  │  - chrome   │  │  - shadcn   │
│  - formulas │  │  - audio    │  │  - etc      │
└─────────────┘  └─────────────┘  └─────────────┘
```

## What Conductor SHOULD Be

A plugin with:
- **Skills** for Chrome/Tabz APIs (progressive disclosure)
- **MCP tools** for browser automation
- **Agents** Claude can spawn for specialized work

What it should NOT have:
- Orchestration commands (bd-work, bd-swarm, wave-done)
- Worker pipelines (worker-done 8-step process)
- Monitoring scripts (monitor-workers.sh)
- PRIME.md with step-by-step instructions
- Context that makes Claude think "I am a worker"

## What Beads Handles

- Issue tracking across sessions
- Dependencies and blockers
- Memory that survives context compaction
- Formulas/molecules for optional structured workflows
- Git-based sync (no tmux notifications needed)

**Key insight:** Beads doesn't bloat the codebase with .md files - it's a proper tracking layer.

## Tasks

### Phase 1: Strip orchestration from conductor
- [ ] Remove commands: bd-work, bd-swarm, wave-done, worker-done, worker-init
- [ ] Remove scripts: monitor-workers.sh, completion-pipeline.sh, wave-summary.sh
- [ ] Remove references: WORKER_PRIME.md, orchestration.md
- [ ] Keep: tabz skills, browser automation, audio/TTS

### Phase 2: Simplify PRIME.md files
- [ ] ~/.beads/PRIME.md → minimal beads reference only
- [ ] Remove "You are a worker" framing
- [ ] Remove step-by-step pipelines
- [ ] Let Claude work naturally

### Phase 3: Remove mcp-cli references (45 files)
- [ ] Replace with MCPSearch tool usage
- [ ] Or direct MCP tool calls
- [ ] Claude discovers tools naturally

### Phase 4: Update CLAUDE.md files
- [ ] Remove conductor orchestration sections
- [ ] Remove worker patterns and tmux nudging
- [ ] Keep project-relevant info only
- [ ] Trust Claude's native capabilities

### Phase 5: Better Codex integration
- [ ] Codex for planning/design review
- [ ] Codex for fast first-pass code review
- [ ] Claude uses it naturally, not via pipeline

## What Remains in Conductor

```
plugins/conductor/
├── skills/
│   ├── automating-browser/    # Chrome automation via tabz
│   ├── using-terminal-tools/  # TUI spawning (btop, lazygit)
│   └── engineering-prompts/   # Prompt crafting (optional)
├── agents/
│   ├── tabz-manager.md        # Browser automation specialist
│   ├── tabz-artist.md         # Asset generation
│   └── tui-expert.md          # TUI tool spawning
└── plugin.json
```

No commands. No orchestration. Just capabilities Claude unlocks as needed.

## Success Criteria

1. Claude naturally uses subagents for parallel work
2. One session can run 1+ hour without context bloat
3. Conductor is just "browser/tabz capabilities"
4. Beads is just "memory/tracking layer"
5. No elaborate pipelines or worker framing
6. mcp-cli references removed (MCPSearch instead)

## Files to Delete

```
plugins/conductor/commands/bd-work.md
plugins/conductor/commands/bd-swarm.md
plugins/conductor/commands/bd-swarm-auto.md
plugins/conductor/commands/wave-done.md
plugins/conductor/commands/worker-done.md
plugins/conductor/commands/worker-init.md
plugins/conductor/commands/orchestration.md
plugins/conductor/scripts/monitor-workers.sh
plugins/conductor/scripts/completion-pipeline.sh

plugins/conductor/references/WORKER_PRIME.md
plugins/conductor/references/bd-work/
plugins/conductor/references/bd-swarm/
~/.beads/PRIME.md (replace with minimal version)
```

## Notes

This is a philosophical shift: stop trying to orchestrate Claude, start enabling Claude.

title: Skip code review and tests for markdown-only changes
description:
The worker-done pipeline runs code-reviewer and test runner even when changes are only to .md files, which is unnecessary overhead.

## Current Behavior
- `/conductor:worker-done` always runs:
  1. Build verification
  2. Test runner
  3. Code reviewer
  4. Commit

- Markdown-only changes (docs, CHANGELOG, README) don't need code review or tests
- Wastes API calls and time
- Research tasks that only update issue notes shouldn't trigger full pipeline

## Proposed Solution
Detect change types before running pipeline:

```bash
# Check if only .md files changed
if git diff --cached --name-only | grep -qvE '\.(md|markdown)$'; then
  # Has non-markdown changes - run full pipeline
  run_tests
  run_code_review
else
  # Markdown only - skip tests/review
  echo "Skipping tests and review for docs-only changes"
fi
```

- `plugins/conductor/scripts/completion-pipeline.sh`

## Edge Cases
- Mixed changes (code + docs) should still run full pipeline
- Config files (.json, .yaml) should probably run review but not tests

title: Add dashboard polling to /conductor:auto
description:
## Problem

The auto loop spawns tmuxplexer dashboard but never polls it:
```bash
spawn_dashboard()  # Spawns but then ignores
```

The dashboard shows worker states (Awaiting Input, Processing, Error) but the conductor never checks this. Workers can get stuck without detection.

## Solution

Add dashboard polling to the main loop:
```bash
# In poll loop
DASHBOARD_SESSION=$(tmux ls | grep -o "ctt-worker-dashboard-[a-f0-9]*")
DASHBOARD_STATE=$(tmux capture-pane -t "$DASHBOARD_SESSION" -p)

# Check for stuck workers
if echo "$DASHBOARD_STATE" | grep -q "Awaiting Input"; then
  echo "WARNING: Worker awaiting input"
  # Could send a nudge or alert
fi
```

Also add individual worker screen capture for debugging:
```bash
curl -s "$TABZ_API/api/tmux/sessions/$SESSION/capture" | jq -r '.data.content' | tail -20
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Poll loop checks dashboard for stuck workers
- [ ] Stuck workers are detected and logged
- [ ] Optional: Send nudge to stuck workers
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Dashboard session name captured after spawn
- [ ] Poll loop checks dashboard for stuck workers
- [ ] Stuck worker detection logged
notes:
## Retro

- Straightforward implementation following the issue description
- Added `check_dashboard_status()` function that polls tmux dashboard
- Dashboard session name captured via API response with fallback to tmux ls pattern
- Detects both "Awaiting Input" and "Error" states
- Worker extraction uses grep patterns to identify which specific workers are stuck
- Did not implement nudge/auto-recovery (marked optional in acceptance criteria)

title: Explore Jira-style issue templates for AI worker prompts
description: Evaluate adopting a Jira-like structure (user story + acceptance criteria + priority/size) for beads issues and worker prompts to improve autonomy and reduce missed steps. Focus on TabzChrome conductor workflows (bd-work/bd-swarm/bd-swarm-auto) and prompt-engineer integration.
design:
## Background
Current workflow uses beads issues plus conductor-orchestrated workers. Prompt quality varies, and steps can be missed when issues lack a crisp story/AC.

## Goal
Adopt a "Jira-lite" template for beads issues to enable workers to be autonomous without overscoping, and to make prioritization/parallelization easier.

## Proposal to explore
### Issue structure (Jira-lite)
- User story: "As a <user>, I want <capability> so that <benefit>."
- Scope:
  - In scope:
  - Out of scope:
- Acceptance criteria (3–7 bullet checkboxes, testable)
- Priority (1–4) and size (S/M/L)
- Dependencies/blockers (beads deps)
- Notes/links (screenshots, file paths)

### Prompt mapping
Worker prompt can be generated directly from issue fields:
- Task header = issue id + title
- Context = user story + scope
- Implementation guardrails = out-of-scope + coding rules
- Done definition = acceptance criteria + pipeline completion command

### Conductor integration ideas
- Add a new command like `/conductor:issue-create` that asks for story + AC + size + labels and creates a beads issue.
- Add a grooming command that converts legacy issues by prompting for missing story/AC.
- Update prompt-engineer to include story/AC verbatim and keep worker autonomy high.

### Measuring success
- Compare before/after on:
  - % of issues completed without conductor intervention
  - frequency of missed pipeline steps (tests/review/commit/push)
  - number of follow-up issues created (good) vs scope creep (bad)
  - lead time per issue and rework rate

### Experiment plan
- Iteration 1: Template only (no enforcement)
- Iteration 2: Add optional creation command
- Iteration 3: Add light gating (warn if missing story/AC)
acceptance_criteria:
- Propose a minimal beads issue template (fields + examples) that maps cleanly to worker prompts
- Recommend how/where to enforce or encourage the template (e.g., a new /conductor command for issue creation)
- Identify what metadata is most useful for parallelization and blockers (labels, deps, size)
- Outline an experiment plan (2–3 iterations) to measure improvement (fewer missed steps, faster completion)
- Keep proposal compatible with existing conductor scripts and does not require immediate code changes

title: Simplify cleanup.md agent to work with gates system
description:
## Problem

The cleanup.md agent was designed as a pre-commit quality gate that:
1. Reviews staged changes
2. Runs checkpoint logic inline
3. Sends feedback to worker via tmux
4. Blocks commit with NEEDS_WORK or allows with PASS

This overlaps with the gate-runner system which now handles quality gates post-close.

## Current Architecture
```
Worker commits → (no gate check) → commit
Worker closes → gate-runner runs /codex-review, /test-runner, etc. → merge
```

## Proposed Change

Simplify cleanup.md to be a lightweight pre-commit check:
1. Verify gates are assigned to this issue (in beads)
2. Check if .checkpoints/ results exist (from previous runs)
3. If gates missing, warn but don't block
4. If checkpoints exist and failed, block commit
5. Don't run checkpoints - that's gate-runner's job

New flow:
```
Worker commits → cleanup agent checks gate status → commit
Worker closes → gate-runner runs gates → merge
```

## Alternative: Remove cleanup.md entirely

If the pre-commit check isn't valuable, remove it and rely entirely on gate-runner post-close.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Decide: simplify or remove
- [ ] If simplify: update cleanup.md to just check gate status
- [ ] If remove: delete cleanup.md and update docs
- [ ] Update conductor documentation to reflect change
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Decision made: simplify or remove
- [ ] Implementation complete
- [ ] Conductor documentation updated
notes:

### Key Files
- `~/plugins/my-plugins/plugins/tools/conductor/agents/cleanup.md` - Agent to simplify or remove
- `~/plugins/my-plugins/plugins/tools/conductor/skills/gate-runner/skill.md` - Current gate system

### Decision Needed
Two options:

**Option A: Simplify cleanup.md**
- Check if gates are assigned to issue (in beads metadata)
- Check if .checkpoints/ results exist
- Warn if gates missing, block only if checkpoints failed
- Dont run gates - thats gate-runners job

**Option B: Remove cleanup.md entirely**
- Delete the agent
- Rely entirely on gate-runner post-close
- Simpler but no pre-commit safety net

### Recommendation
Option A - simplify to lightweight status check. Pre-commit gate still has value.

### Testing
- Test with issue that has gates assigned
- Test with issue missing gates
- Verify commit blocking works

## Retro
- Decision: Chose Option A (simplify, not remove) - pre-commit check has value but shouldnt duplicate gate-runner work
- What was unclear: The exact location of gate-runner skill (it was actually commands/gate-runner.md not skills/)
- Implementation: Rewrote cleanup.md to just check status of existing checkpoints and gate assignments
- Documentation: Updated gate-runner.md with two-phase quality system diagram and explanation

title: Refactor tabz MCP tools for progressive disclosure (reduce 36K tokens)
description:
## Problem

Tabz MCP server uses ~36K tokens for 70 tools (~514 tokens/tool average). This is 10-15x more than typical MCP tools due to verbose descriptions with examples, error handling, troubleshooting, and "when to use X vs Y" guidance embedded in each tool.

## Solution

Use MCP's progressive disclosure features:

### 1. Minimal tool descriptions
```typescript
// Before (~1,500 chars)
"Capture a screenshot of the current browser viewport...
Use this tool when you need to see "what I see"...
Examples:
  - "Screenshot my view" → tabz_screenshot...
Error Handling:
  - "No active tab": No browser tab is open..."

// After (~100 chars)  
"Capture visible viewport. Returns filePath. Options: selector, tabId."
```

### 2. MCP Resources for detailed docs
```typescript
server.resource("docs/screenshot-tools", "text/markdown", async () => {
  return { contents: [{ text: fs.readFileSync("docs/screenshot.md") }] };
});
```

### 3. MCP Prompts for common workflows
```typescript
server.prompt("screenshot-guide", "How to use screenshot tools", async () => {
  return { messages: [{ role: "user", content: detailedGuide }] };
});
```

## Files to modify

- `tabz-mcp-server/src/tools/*.ts` - Trim all tool descriptions
- `tabz-mcp-server/src/resources/` - Create docs resources (new)
- `tabz-mcp-server/src/prompts/` - Create workflow prompts (new)
- `tabz-mcp-server/docs/` - Move detailed docs here

## Expected result

- Tool schemas: ~36K → ~5-8K tokens
- Detailed docs available on-demand via resources
- Common workflows as slash commands via prompts

## References

- MCP Resources: https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/concepts/resources
- MCP Prompts: https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/concepts/prompts

title: Merge prompt engineering into conductor workflows, remove prompt-drafter
description:
## Problem

The current conductor architecture has a design flaw:

1. **prompt-drafter uses Haiku** - Haiku is not good at nuanced prompt crafting. Worker prompt quality matters.

2. **prompt-engineer is for Opus, but conductor IS Opus** - The conductor runs on Opus 4.5, so calling out to a separate prompt-engineer agent is redundant. The knowledge should be baked in.

3. **draft-prompts command adds unnecessary indirection** - Conductor should craft prompts directly as part of bd-swarm/bd-swarm-auto workflows.

## Current State

```
Conductor (Opus)
  └── draft-prompts command
        └── prompt-drafter agent (Haiku) ← Bad: Haiku crafting prompts
              └── Returns prompt

prompt-engineer agent (Opus) ← Redundant: Conductor is already Opus
```

## Proposed Solution

```
Conductor (Opus)
  └── Worker Prompt Guidelines (baked into workflow docs)
        └── Crafts prompts directly using best practices
```

### Changes Required

**1. Merge prompt engineering best practices into conductor workflows:**

Add a "Worker Prompt Guidelines" section to bd-swarm.md and/or worker-architecture.md covering:
- Be explicit (Claude 4.x follows instructions precisely)
- Add context (explain WHY, not just WHAT)
- Plain text file paths (not @file references that auto-load)
- Skill hints as natural language triggers

description:

Currently the conductor spawns the dashboard but never reads its output. The dashboard shows valuable info:

- Status (🟡 Processing [47%])
- Current command being run
- Working directory and git branch
- Context window usage percentage

1. During poll loop, capture dashboard pane:
```bash
tmux capture-pane -t ctt-worker-dashboard-* -p -S -100
```

2. Parse the output to extract worker status:
- Session name (e.g., V4V-0fw)
- State icon (🟢 Idle, 🟡 Processing, 🔧 Tool Use, ⏸️ Awaiting Input)
- Context percentage [47%]
- Current tool/command

3. Use this to determine:
- Worker is actively processing (don't interrupt)
- Worker is idle/awaiting input (may need prompt)
- Worker is stale (no updates for 60s+)

## Alternative: Read Claude state files directly

Claude writes state to `/tmp/claude-code-state/*.json`:
```json
{
  "session_id": "...",
  "status": "processing",
  "current_tool": "Bash",
  "context_pct": 47,
  "tmux_pane": "%5"
}
```

## Tmuxplexer Dashboard Flag

Use `./tmuxplexer --watcher` to spawn the dashboard:
- Full terminal height for sessions list (no preview/command panels)
- **Defaults to AI-only filter** (FilterAI)
- Perfect for conductor poll loop monitoring

The poll loop should:
1. Spawn: `./tmuxplexer --watcher` in ~/projects/tmuxplexer
2. Capture: `tmux capture-pane -t <session> -p -S -100`
3. Parse: Extract session names, status icons (🔧/🟡/🟢), context % ([38%])

## Context Management

**For Conductor (self-management):**
- Conductor is stateless between iterations - all state lives in beads + tmuxplexer
- When conductor's own context ≥ 70%, can safely `/wipe:wipe` and resume with `gg-auto`
- No PRIME.md needed - the auto command re-establishes orchestration context

**For Workers:**
- Workers need PRIME.md for codebase context
- Auto-compact is enabled with beads hook to re-inject PRIME.md on compact
- Conductor can suggest `/wipe` but workers handle their own context via auto-compact

**Key insight:** Conductor can monitor its OWN context % from tmuxplexer and self-restart when needed, since it's just running a loop and doesn't need deep codebase knowledge.

title: Spawner: Handle Python venv in worktrees
description:
The init-worktree.sh script may skip Python dependency installation if .venv already exists in the main repo.

When creating a worktree, the script checks for .venv and skips creating one if it exists. But worktrees share the same file system as main, so the .venv from main may be visible but not properly linked.

Observed: When spawning a worker for V4V-bp7 (Python backend), the init script only showed npm install for frontend, not Python deps for backend.
design:
## Options

### Option 1: Symlink main .venv
Worktrees could symlink to the main repo's .venv since deps are identical:
```bash
if [ ! -d "$dir/.venv" ] && [ -d "$MAIN_REPO/$dir/.venv" ]; then
  ln -s "$MAIN_REPO/$dir/.venv" "$dir/.venv"
fi
```

### Option 2: Force fresh venv per worktree
Always create a new .venv in the worktree:
```bash
# Skip the exists check for worktrees
if git rev-parse --is-inside-work-tree &>/dev/null && [ -f ".git" ]; then
  # This is a worktree, always init fresh
  rm -rf .venv
fi
```

### Option 3: Check if venv is actually usable
```bash
if [ -d "$dir/.venv" ]; then
  # Verify it's a real venv, not a dangling reference
  if [ ! -f "$dir/.venv/bin/python" ]; then
    rm -rf "$dir/.venv"  # Clean up broken venv
  fi
fi
```

## Recommendation

Option 1 (symlink) is fastest and saves disk space. The deps are identical across worktrees.

- [ ] Backend Python deps are installed or linked
- [ ] Works for both uv and standard venv

## Worker Prompt: Handle Python venv Symlink in Worktrees

Fix the Python venv issue where worktrees skip installation if .venv exists in main repo due to shared filesystem.

### Implementation Steps

1. **Detect if .venv is a symlink**
   - In `install_python()`, before `cd "$dir"`, check: `if [ -L "$dir/.venv" ]`
   - If already symlinked, skip venv creation and activation
   
2. **Create symlink to main .venv**

   - Create symlink: `ln -s "$MAIN_REPO/.venv" "$dir/.venv"`

3. **Fallback to fresh venv if needed**

4. **Update activation logic**

5. **Test cases to verify**

title: Conductor subagent helpers for long-running orchestration workflows
description:
Enable conductors to use subagents for delegated tasks during bd-swarm/bd-swarm-auto workflows, allowing multi-hour autonomous operation.

## Problem
Conductors run without --agent flag to spawn subagents, but currently don't use them. This limits workflow duration:
- Conductor manually sets up worktrees (context waste)
- No context monitoring → conductor hits limits mid-workflow
- No handoff mechanism → can't continue after context full
- Manual orchestration overhead for multi-hour tasks

## Proposed Subagent Use Cases

### 1. Worktree Setup Agent
**When:** bd-swarm issues spawn request
**Agent:** Quick background agent to run setup-worktree.sh
**Benefit:** Conductor stays focused on orchestration, not setup tasks

### 2. Context Monitor Agent  
**When:** Long-running bd-swarm-auto workflows
**Agent:** Background agent that monitors conductor context %
**Action:** At ~70% context, sends tmux message: "Context at 70% - consider handoff"
**Benefit:** Prevents mid-workflow context exhaustion

### 3. Conductor Handoff Agent
**When:** Context monitor triggers at 70%+
**Agent:** Spawns new conductor session with summary prompt
**Prompt:** `/conductor:orchestration - You are the new conductor. Previous session summary: [state]"`
**Benefit:** Seamless multi-hour workflows with context reset

### 4. Worker Monitor Agent (Alternative to script)
**When:** bd-swarm spawns workers
**Agent:** Monitors worker tmux sessions for completion
**Action:** Alerts conductor when all workers done
**Benefit:** Native Claude monitoring vs bash polling

## Design Considerations

**Subagent activation:**
- Explicit Task() calls in conductor commands
- model: haiku for monitoring/setup tasks (cheap, fast)
- model: sonnet only for complex orchestration decisions

**Context handoff protocol:**
```bash
# At 70% context:
1. Subagent captures current state (bd stats, active workers, wave progress)
2. Spawns new conductor via TabzChrome API
3. Sends handoff prompt with state summary
4. Old conductor gracefully exits after handoff confirmed
```

**Integration points:**
- bd-swarm.md: Add worktree-setup-agent Task() call
- bd-swarm-auto.md: Add context-monitor-agent at start
- orchestration.md: Document subagent patterns
- PRIME.md: Add "Use subagents for setup/monitoring tasks" guideline
design:

### Pattern 1: Parallel Worktree Setup

```typescript
for issue in issues:
  Task(
    subagent_type="general-purpose",
    model="haiku",
    description="Setup worktree",

```

### Pattern 2: Context Monitor (Background)

```typescript
  subagent_type="general-purpose", 
  model="haiku",
  run_in_background=true,
  description="Monitor context usage",

```

### Pattern 3: Handoff Orchestrator

```typescript
  subagent_type="general-purpose",
  model="sonnet",  
  description="Handoff to new conductor",
  prompt="""
  Current state:
  - Active workers: [list]

  Spawn new conductor session with summary and continue orchestration.

```

description:
Create a prompt-engineer subagent that helps write optimal prompts for Claude 4.x models.

## Reference
Anthropic official guide: https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/build-with-claude/prompting-best-practices

## Core Patterns to Include

### Be Explicit
- Claude 4.x follows instructions precisely
- Say "make changes" not "suggest changes" if you want action
- Frame with modifiers: "Include as many relevant features as possible"

### Add Context
- Explain WHY, not just WHAT
- Claude generalizes from explanations
- Example: "Your response will be read aloud by TTS, so never use ellipses"

### Soften Aggressive Language
- Replace "CRITICAL: You MUST..." with "Use this when..."
- Opus 4.5 is more responsive to system prompts, may overtrigger

### Thinking Sensitivity
- When extended thinking disabled, replace "think" with:
  - "consider", "evaluate", "believe"

### Standard Blocks

```xml
<default_to_action>
Implement changes rather than only suggesting them.
If unclear, infer the most useful action and proceed.
</default_to_action>

<investigate_before_answering>
Never speculate about code you have not opened.
Read relevant files BEFORE answering questions.
</investigate_before_answering>

<use_parallel_tool_calls>
If no dependencies between tool calls, make all independent calls in parallel.
</use_parallel_tool_calls>

<avoid_excessive_markdown_and_bullet_points>
Write in clear, flowing prose using complete paragraphs.
Reserve markdown for inline code, code blocks, and simple headings.
</avoid_excessive_markdown_and_bullet_points>

<frontend_aesthetics>
Avoid generic AI slop aesthetic.
Focus on: Typography, Color/Theme, Motion, Backgrounds.
Make creative, distinctive frontends.
</frontend_aesthetics>
```

### Anti-Over-Engineering
```
Avoid over-engineering. Only make changes directly requested.
Dont add features or refactor beyond what was asked.
Dont create helpers for one-time operations.
```

## Agent Structure
- Model: opus (for complex prompt crafting)
- Skills: sequential-thinking (for multi-step prompt design)
- Include the full reference guide in references/

title: Research skill-cortex-server for dynamic skill injection
description:
Evaluate skill-cortex-server MCP for dynamically injecting skills into conductor worker prompts based on beads issue context.

## Repo
https://github.com/Sim-xia/skill-cortex-server

## Concept
Instead of hardcoding skills per project, conductor could:
1. Search skill-cortex for relevant skills based on issue title/labels
2. Inject matching skills into worker prompts automatically
3. Access 28k+ skills from skillsmp.com database

## To Evaluate
- Code quality (currently 7/10 - decent but early)
- Integration with conductor skill-picker agent
- Performance of skill search at scale
- Whether to fork/extend or build similar
notes:
## Research Findings (2026-01-07)

### skill-cortex-server Overview

**Version:** 0.1.0 (early-stage)
**Stack:** Python 3.11+, MCP 0.9+
**Repo:** https://github.com/Sim-xia/skill-cortex-server

### Architecture

4 MCP tools:
1. `list_skill_tree` - Hierarchical skill browsing
2. `search_skills` - Text + tag search
3. `get_skill_details` - Fetch raw SKILL.md content
4. `update_tags` - Manage skill tags

Skills are scanned from filesystem (`~/.claude/skills`, `./.skills`).
No persistent cache - rescans on every startup.

### Skill Sources (via import script)

1. anthropics/skills (official)
2. agentskills/agentskills
3. huggingface/skills
4. ComposioHQ/awesome-claude-skills

### Comparison: skill-cortex vs conductor:skill-picker

| Feature | skill-cortex | skill-picker |
|---------|-------------|---------------|
| Skill count | ~100s (4 repos) | 28,000+ (skillsmp.com) |
| Search | Substring | AI semantic |
| Ranking | None | Star-based |
| Dependency | Local Python | External API |
| Indexing | Filesystem scan | None needed |
| MCP native | Yes | No (curl-based) |

### Code Quality Assessment: 6/10

**Pros:**
- Clean MCP implementation using FastMCP
- Proper data models (frozen dataclasses)
- Path traversal protection via index lookup
- Modular design (scanner, index_store, server)

**Cons:**
- No caching (rescans every time)
- Basic substring search (not semantic)
- Early version with limited testing
- Raw markdown returned without sanitization (prompt injection risk)

### Integration Verdict: NOT RECOMMENDED for replacement

**skill-picker wins because:**
1. 280x more skills (28k vs ~100s)
2. AI semantic search (much better relevance)
3. Star-based quality ranking
4. Already integrated with conductor

**skill-cortex could complement for:**
- Local skill inventory management
- Hierarchical browsing UI in dashboard
- Project-specific skills not on skillsmp

### Recommended Next Steps

1. **Keep skill-picker as primary** - No change needed
2. **Consider skill-cortex for local catalog** - Optional future enhancement
3. **If extending skill-cortex:**
   - Add persistent caching (JSON or SQLite)
   - Add skillsmp.com API as secondary source
   - Add semantic search via embeddings
   - Consider TypeScript rewrite for TabzChrome consistency

### Conclusion

skill-cortex-server is a decent MCP wrapper for local skill management, but skill-picker's connection to skillsmp.com provides far more value. No integration work recommended at this time.
close_reason: Research complete - NOT RECOMMENDED for integration, existing skill-picker is superior
